title: 108_s2790
content: The Act may be cited as the "Bisti PRLA Dispute Resolution Act" and involves the withdrawal of coal preference right lease applications. The "Bisti PRLA Dispute Resolution Act" allows for the issuance of bidding rights certificates to holders who withdraw coal preference right lease applications, based on fair market value. Relinquishment of all associated rights is required for withdrawn applications. The Act allows for the issuance of bidding rights certificates to holders who withdraw coal preference right lease applications based on fair market value. Relinquishment of all associated rights is required for withdrawn applications, without further adjudication by the Secretary. Relinquishment of all associated rights is required for withdrawn applications, without further adjudication by the Secretary. SEC. 3. METHOD FOR DETERMINING FAIR MARKET VALUE. The Act allows for the determination of fair market value of coal reserves for withdrawn coal preference right lease applications through a panel established by the Secretary within 30 days of enactment. The panel, composed of 3 representatives appointed by the Secretary, holder of the preference right lease application, and Governor of New Mexico, will determine the fair market value of a coal reserve with the assistance of a qualified coal reserve appraiser. The panel, composed of 3 representatives, will determine the fair market value of a coal reserve with the assistance of a qualified appraiser. The panel may supplement information as needed and must submit their determination to the Secretary within 75 days. SEC. 4. Patents issued for relinquished preference right lease applications. The Secretary must issue patents to the Navajo Nation for land, including mineral rights, within 120 days of withdrawing a coal preference right lease application. This is to satisfy the Navajo Nation's land selection rights and promote land consolidation and mineral development in northwest New Mexico. Additionally, a certificate of bidding rights must be issued based on fair market value. The Secretary must issue patents to the Navajo Nation for land, including mineral rights, within 120 days of withdrawing a coal preference right lease application to promote mineral development in northwest New Mexico. A certificate of bidding rights must be issued based on fair market value, and enforcement of the Secretary's duties is considered nondiscretionary and enforceable. SEC. 5. USE OF EXCHANGE BIDDING RIGHTS. The certificate of bidding rights issued under section 4(a)(2) allows for transferability and can be used as a monetary credit against payments for Federal coal leases. The certificate of bidding rights issued under section 4(a)(2) can be used as a monetary credit against payments for Federal coal leases, allowing holders to apply it against 50 percent of the amount payable under the lease. The certificate of bidding rights issued under section 4(a)(2) allows holders to apply it as a credit against 50 percent of the payment obligation for a Federal coal lease. The remaining 50 percent must be paid in cash or cash equivalent as specified in the lease. Payments made using the certificate shall be treated as money received under the Mineral Leasing Act and distributed accordingly by the Secretary. The Secretary shall credit and redistribute payments from Federal coal leases as follows: 50% in cash to the State where the lease is located, and 50% through crediting of bidding rights subject to redistribution to Treasury accounts.
